intro: Tristemon stellatus var. bigelowii, commonly known as the Bigelow's star twiner, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, star-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows as a twining vine with hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually pink to purple, with five petals and a prominent central stamen, and bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and stream banks.
